title: 'Consider Polling Agents Special Voters'
text:
Politics | 14 October 2015 15:53 CET 'Consider Polling Agents Special Voters' By Daily Guide 
The Let My Vote Count Alliance (LMVCA) is advocating the inclusion of polling station agents of the various political parties and candidates in the list of special voters by the Electoral Commission (EC). 
The list has often included security personnel, journalists, EC officials and polling agents of the political parties and their respective candidates. 
But this time around, the EC is reported to have declared its intention not to add polling agents to the list of people who will be given the opportunity to vote ahead of the actual day of the polls in view of their special roles in election monitoring and security. 
It is in view of this that the LMVCA says they are alarmed by the intention of the EC not to allow polling agents of candidates to be added to the special voters' list. 
In a statement, a leading member of the group, Ibrahim Adjei, referred to the 'Public Election Regulations, 2012 (C.I. 75) which allows for election officers and others, particularly security agents who, because of their special duties on polling day, may not be able to vote, to vote before polling day. 
'Our understanding is that the EC made it clear to political parties at the last IPAC meeting that it had no intention to allow polling agents to join the list of special voters,' he said, adding, 'we are perplexed by this decision' since 'it goes against all that the nation is seeking to do for future elections: enhancing vigilance and credibility.' 
According to him, 'it would be a big blow to all the serious efforts to increase vigilance if the EC goes ahead with this' and that 'limiting political parties or candidates to choose their agents just from the very polling station area those agents are to be recruited to work will be most odd and counterproductive.' 
Basis He recalled how in 2012 the EC denied journalists the opportunity to cast their ballots earlier as special voters, which, according to him, affected the effective monitoring of the polls. 
This, Ibrahim Adjei said, was because 'media houses could not do freely what they were able to do in previous elections where journalists were allowed on the special votersâ€™ list' and that it also 'reduced the opportunity for several media houses to deploy their best personnel widely, especially in the several known hot spots across Ghana.' 
The group said in a country where election results can be determined by a small margin of 40,000 votes, the parties should not be forced into making the difficult choice of losing votes for the sake of picking vigilant people to protect ballots. LMVCA therefore insisted that 'candidates must be allowed the flexibility to recruit widely to deploy widely based on need.' 
By Charles Takyi-Boadu
